title: PM Orban: Many Want War + Video
body: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not that there is some master plan somewhere, with an evil figure sitting in the background pulling the strings,‚Äù PM Orban said in a video uploaded to his social media page. ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs happening is that there is a military conflict, and everyone has begun looking for what opportunities it might hold for them.‚ÄùHungary's Prime Minister Viktor Orban warns of the dangers of war (Photo: AFP)The prime minister added:That is why many people want war‚Äîbut not all for the same reason. title: Marton Nagy: Brussels Is Banking on Toppling of Hungarian Government
body: In an interview for Index.hu,National Economy Minister Marton Nagystressed that the previously forecast 3‚Äì6 percent economic growth and the anticipated ‚Äúflying start‚Äù were entirely realistic. ‚ÄúThe Hungarian economy is capable of this,‚Äù he said. Under normal circumstances in 2025, domestic demand alone would have added roughly two percentage points to GDP growth. Had the German economy not been in recession, external demand could have contributed another two percentage points‚Äîbringing total growth close to four percent, he added.Hungary's National Economy Minister Marton Nagy (Photo: MTI/Zoltan Kocsis)The situation, however, has since changed. Consumption is still delivering its two percentage points, but Germany‚Äôs economic slowdown, delayed investments, and excess capacity are together retracting roughly two percentage points from growth. As a result, overall expansion now stands at between zero and one percent.‚ÄúIf the government were not protecting households through real wage increases, we wouldn‚Äôt be slightly in the black‚Äîwe‚Äôd be in the red,‚Äù Nagy said.According to the minister, two major dependencies have clearly emerged in the Hungarian economy: one on Germany, and the other on the automotive industry. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs no point denying this,‚Äù he said. Eastern investments‚Äîprimarily from China and South Korea‚Äîhave not reduced this exposure but have actually reinforced it. Battery plants, after all, ultimately serve German car manufacturers, and even BYD is producing not for the Hungarian market but largely for Germany.Between 2010 and 2020, however, this dependency posed no problem, Nagy noted. The automotive sector was one of the main engines of the Hungarian economy, and Germany‚Äôs strong performance translated into robust growth and rapid convergence for Hungary. When the automotive industry began its transition to electric vehicles, abandoning the sector was never an option. The battery industry, he emphasized, is not a standalone sector but a supplier to electric vehicle manufacturing.Relocating battery plants to Hungary was therefore a deliberate and sound decision aimed at preserving this key industry. ‚ÄúThe real problem,‚Äù Nagy added, ‚Äúis that it‚Äôs not enough to stand on just one leg‚Äîeven if that leg is strong.‚Äù The task now, he said, is to build additional pillars: in services, logistics, the food and pharmaceutical industries, and the defense sector.At the same time, Hungary must address the issue of its dual economy‚Äînamely, the excessive gap between large multinational corporations and domestic small and medium-sized enterprises.Asked whether it is risky for the state budget to be repeatedly based on growth assumptions that fail to materialize, Nagy responded that this would only be dangerous if lower growth automatically created a large budget hole. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs not what‚Äôs happening now,‚Äù he said. What matters from a budgetary standpoint is the source of the weaker growth. The 2025 budget was planned with 3.4 percent growth in mind, while the actual figure may come in closer to 0.5 percent‚Äîbut the revenue shortfall is not proportional to that difference. This is because the slowdown is primarily due to postponed investments, not a collapse in consumption.

title: ‚ÄúHeading to Vote on New Asphalt Is Good‚Äù ‚Äì PM Orban Opens Hungary‚Äôs New Motorway
body: Speaking at the opening ceremony, PM Orban recalled that it was Sandor Fazekas who reviewed the nationwide road development proposal and asked, ‚ÄúBut what about them?‚Äù referring to the region. ‚ÄúWe owe him thanks for ensuring this road was never taken off the agenda,‚Äù Viktor Orban said. He added that he also learned from Fazekas that ‚Äúit‚Äôs best when people go to vote on steaming asphalt.‚Äù The prime minister thanked local residents for their past electoral support, saying that kind of backing is still needed today.Mr. Orban also remarked that it is unwise to cross the Kun people, noting that they produced Hungary‚Äôs last regent, who was from Kenderes, and occasionally they even contribute a Nobel Prize winner to the nation. He emphasized that the government has its own development program for the Great Plain, adding that unemployment in the region has dropped from 12 percent to 5 percent since 2010.‚ÄúThe major expense, however, was the two roads, because the M44 was also critically important,‚Äù the PM said. ‚ÄúThere are still 60 kilometers left to build, and that will be done as well.‚ÄùPhoto: MTI/Prime Minister's Office Communications Department/Zoltan FischerIndustrial Zones Linked by MotorwaysThe prime minister announced that starting January 1, 2026, trucks weighing more than 20 tons will be permitted to use only motorways. He noted that thanks to post-2010 motorway construction, Hungary‚Äîon a per-capita basis‚Äîhas caught up with even the most developed countries. As a result, 22 county-level cities are now accessible by motorway.‚ÄúIf we can carry out all our plans, every Hungarian will live no more than 20 minutes from a highway,‚Äù Orban said. He outlined ambitious plans for the region, including the creation of an industrial zone linking Debrecen, Nagyszalonta, and Bekescsaba. As part of this effort, construction of the Debrecen‚ÄìBekescsaba expressway will begin soon.Two Paths Before HungaryPM Orban stressed that Hungary managed‚Äîafter a hard fight‚Äîto stay out of a Brussels-backed loan scheme. ‚ÄúFor Hungarians, that would have meant a cost of 400 billion forints,‚Äù he said, noting that the newly opened road section cost 170 billion forints. ‚ÄúThis money has a better place here than in the pockets of an oligarch in the shot-to-pieces Donbas.‚Äù

title: PM Orban: Next Year‚Äôs Election Could Decide Between War and Peace
body: Speaking on TV2‚Äôs Tenyek program, Prime Minister Viktor Orb√°n said the anti-war rallies provide an opportunity to explain to the public what is happening behind closed doors as Europe prepares for war. He emphasized that European leaders at the summit held what amounted to a war council over the weekend, where speeches were clearly focused on defeating Russia. PM Orban noted that since DonaldTrump‚Äôsinauguration in January, the U.S. president is doing exactly what he promised, which is creating a growing divide between American and European policy.Previously it was unthinkable within NATO that the United States would say no to something and European states would still go ahead and do it,the prime minister said.A War-Free Christmas‚Äîfor NowPM Orban stressed that Europe is far closer to war than the Hungarian public can imagine, and that the anti-war rallies help make this reality tangible. He recalled a German war plan aimed at seizing Russia's currency reserves in Western Europe, a move that would have overtly turned Europe into Russia‚Äôs enemy. That plan had to be stopped, he said. Hungary did its part, but the decisive push came from what Mr. Orban called the heroic stance of the Belgian prime minister, who ultimately said no to the Germans.Italy and France did not abandon Belgium, so the Germans were unable to push their proposal through,he noted.The prime minister emphasized that Hungary will now have a war-free Christmas, but warned that the danger of war has not passed. The European Union wants to provide Ukraine with ‚Ç¨90 billion over two years, but the EU has no money of its own. Instead, it turned to bankers for loans‚Äîloans, he said that will never be repaid. Slovakia, the Czech Republic, and Hungary refused to provide guarantees for the borrowing, unwilling to put taxpayers‚Äô money into what he described as a dubious financial maneuver.This would have cost Hungarian families 400 billion forints. We will not pay that‚Äîfull stop,Viktor Orban declared.Whoever Gains Time, Gains LifeOverall, PM Orban said, Europe has more assets in Russia‚Äîthrough private companies‚Äîthan the amount the EU would have seized. He added that Hungary also holds significant assets in Russia through major corporations.
